meta.title: Amino Acids Catabolism, Urea Cycle & Associated Disorders

questions.text: The proteins in the body undergo constant turnover; that is, they are constantly being degraded to amino acids and resynthesized. However, the healthy human adult is in nitrogen balance. All of the following are conditions associated with negative nitrogen balance, EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Convalescence Healthy adults will be at a state of nitrogen equilibrium, i.e. nitrogen intake = Nitrogen excreted. A high protein intake does not lead to a positive nitrogen balance since high protein intake also leads to protein degradation. A large intake of proteins is not advised since protein synthesis and protein degradation are energy-expensive processes.

questions.text: The ammonia released from the amino acid catabolism is first converted to carbamoyl phosphate after a reaction with CO2. In ureotelic animals, the carbamoyl group is further transferred to:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ornithine The question is asking about the first step of the urea cycle in an indirect way (See Fig). See the attached treasure for urea cycle steps. Based on how nitrogen is excreted, animals are divided into 3 categories. Ammoniotelic animals - Animals that excrete ammonia. e.g. Fishes Ureotelic animals - Animals that excrete urea e.g. Mammals including man Uricotelic - Animals that excrete uric aciduric acid. e.g. Birds

questions.text: Nitric oxide acts by increasing:-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

cGMP NO (Nitric oxide) activates the enzyme Guanyl cyclase which converts GTP to cyclic GMP Cyclic GMP causes relaxation of smooth muscle cells by mechanism as shown in Fig:

questions.text: Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS-I) enzyme present in mitochondria is involved in the first and rate-limiting step of the urea cycle. Which of the following is the allosteric activator of CPS-I?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

N-acetyl glutamate N-Acetyl Glutamate (NAG) is synthesized from N-acetyl glutamate synthase or NAG synthase, for which arginine is the activator. NAGS is regarded as the 6th enzyme of the urea cycle. NAG is an allosteric activator of CPS-I (Rate Limiting Enzyme).

questions.text: The urea cycle is a major pathway for converting harmful ammonia to relatively harmless urea for excretion. Cellular sites involved in this conversion are mitochondria and cytoplasm. Which of the following urea cycle reaction(s) take place in mitochondria? Arginase Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase 1 Argininosuccinate lyase Argininosuccinate synthetase Ornithine transcarbamylase Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2, & 5 are correct There are 5 enzymatic reactions in the urea cycle. The first two, that is CPS I & Ornithine Transcarbamoylase (OTC) take place inside the mitochondria and the rest takes place inside the cytosol. CPS I is the regulator of the urea cycle, as it is a rate-limiting step CPS I is a hepatic mitochondrial enzyme NOTE: CPS-II is involved in pyrimidine synthesis in the cytoplasm

questions.text: Which of the following urea cycle intermediate is the link between the urea cycle and TCA cycle?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fumarate Fumarate is the link between the urea cycle and the TCA cycle Urea Bicycle = Urea cycle + TCA cycle Both are independent cycles but are linked. 1 nitrogen in the urea is obtained from the aspartate obtained by transamination of oxaloacetate produced in the TCA cycle The fumarate that is produced in the urea cycle can be used as an intermediate in the citric acid cycle (See fig).

questions.text: Glutamate releases ammonia in the liver by undergoing oxidative deamination using an enzyme, which can then enter the urea cycle. The enzyme of oxidative deamination is Glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH) which requires a cofactor in the form of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both a & b Glutamate dehydrogenase is a special enzyme that can use either NAD or NADP . It is involved in oxidative deamination in the liver.

Extraedge:

Glutamate is the only amino acid that can undergo rapid oxidative deamination.

questions.text: Free ammonia is highly toxic to the brain and has to be removed quickly. Which intermediate of the citric acid cycle is used in the detoxification of ammonia in the brain?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Alpha-ketoglutarate When ammonia is present in the body in large amount ( hyperammonemia ), then this alpha-ketoglutarate (α-KG) of TCA combines with one amino group to form glutamate Further glutamate combines with the second amino group to form glutamine Glutamine is a safe form of ammonia storage & transport. Alpha-ketoglutarate is depleted, which affects the TCA cycle. That’s why the brain is affected as the first organ (The brain is highly aerobic tissue).

questions.text: Nitrogenous wastes tend to form ammonia which is toxic and also raises the pH of body fluids. The animals must detoxify ammonia by converting it into a relatively nontoxic form such as urea or uric acid. Which one of the following is a symptom of ammonia intoxication?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Slurring of speech One of the earliest symptoms of ammonia intoxication is haziness of vision and slurring of speech Other clinical features of urea cycle defects: Increased blood glutamine Decreased BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen) Cerebral edema Vomiting Lethargy hyperventilation Note : Severe ammonia toxicity can lead to coma and eventually death

questions.text: The urea molecule consists of two nitrogen atoms and one carbon atom. In the biosynthesis of urea, one nitrogen atom is derived from ammonia while the other nitrogen atom is from which of the following amino acid?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aspartate Nitrogen atoms of urea are derived from : N 1 from a mmonia N 2 from Aspartate Source of urea Carbon and Nitrogen.

questions.text: Urea cycle and the Tricarboxylic acid cycle work in combination for the maintenance of nitrogen and amino acid pool in the body. Which is the common amino acid between the urea cycle and TCA?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aspartate In the Urea cycle : Aspartate (an amino acid) provides the second nitrogen of urea (the first nitrogen is from free ammonia). Fumarate is also common in the urea cycle & TCA, but fumarate is not an amino acid. As the Question specifically asks about amino acid, Hence the answer is aspartate and not fumarate. In TCA: Fumarate from the urea cycle enters the TCA cycle and gets converted to malate, then oxaloacetate, which forms aspartate via transamination Then aspartate enters the urea cycle in the arginosuccinate synthetase step.

questions.text: A patient presented to the casualty with nausea, and vomiting. Intravenous glucose was given & the patient recovered. After a few months, the patient presented with the same complaints. Blood glutamine was found to be increased. Also, uracil levels were raised. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency An increase in Blood glutamine indicates hyperammonemia , which occurs in all enzyme defects of the urea cycle Increased uracil indicates Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency Orotic acid, OMP, and UMP are increased in OTC defect. OTC deficiency (Excess carbamoyl phosphate from mitochondria enters the cytoplasm and takes part in pyrimidine synthesis)

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- If citrulline is increased then it is Argininosuccinate synthetase deficiency. (OPTION II) CPS-II (carbamoyl phosphate synthetase-II) is the enzyme involved in pyrimidine synthesis, not in the urea cycle. (OPTION III)

questions.text: Amino acid metabolism provides as well as utilizes a number of TCA intermediates. The catabolic product of which of the following amino acid enters the TCA cycle at the succinyl-CoA step?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Methionine Catabolic products of the following 4 amino acids enter TCA at the Succinyl-CoA step: Valine Isoleucine Methionine Threonine

questions.text: The blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN) test is a widely used renal function test to know the problem related to the kidneys. Which of the following conditions will cause a decrease in BUN?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hyperammonemia Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN) is decreased in urea cycle defects where Hyperammonemia BUN measures the urea content of blood formed from the urea cycle. A defect in the urea cycle enzyme will cause low urea formation and decreased BUN. C/f of urea cycle defects: Increased blood glutamine Decreased BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen Cerebral edema Vomiting Lethargy Blurred vision Slurred speech & hyperventilation.

questions.text: Ammonia produced in different organs and tissues by catabolism of non-protein nitrogenous substances has to be transported to the liver for the formation of urea. Which amino acid is regarded as a collector of amino groups?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glutamate The first step in the catabolism of amino acids is the transfer of the NH 3 group from amino acid to Alpha Keto- Glutarate forming Glutamate- known as Transamination . So, Glutamate is regarded as a collector of amino groups. Note: The safe non-toxic form of ammonia transport in blood from most body tissues is Glutamine . A collector is Glutamate, the transporter is Glutamine

questions.text: Glutamate dehydrogenase plays a key role in ammonia release and incorporation in animals and microbes in association with glutamine synthetase. Out of the following, which is the allosteric activator of hepatic glutamate dehydrogenase?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

ADP Glutamate dehydrogenase: Involved in the oxidative deamination of glutamate to form alpha-ketoglutarate Present in mitochondria of liver cells Can use either NAD or NADP This reaction is reversible Allosteric activator Allosteric inhibitor ● NAD ● ADP ● GDP ● ATP ● GTP ● NADH So, options a, b, and d are allosteric inhibitors.

questions.text: Transamination is the first step in amino acid catabolism and serves to transfer of NH3 group from an amino acid to alpha-ketoglutarate to form glutamate. All of the following are transaminated EXCEPT:
questions.correct_answer: B. α- amino group of proline
questions.explanation:
Solution:

α- amino group of proline Transamination is not restricted to alpha-amino groups. The delta amino group of ornithine (but not the ε-amino group of lysine) readily undergoes transamination with the help of enzyme δ-OAT (Ornithine Amino Transferase)

Extraedge:

Out of the 20 amino acids, 3 amino acids do not take part in transamination . Mnemonic to remember the amino acids which don't undergo transamination: POLYTHENE PO - Proline/Hydroxyproline LY - Lysine THENE - Threonine

questions.text: In all of the following enzyme deficiencies, hyperammonemia is a common feature, EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ornithine aminotransferase Excess ornithine from the urea cycle is taken by the enzyme OAT (Ornithine aminotransferase) OAT deficiency leads to gyrate atrophy. In this deficiency, plasma, urine, spinal fluid and aqueous humor concentration of ornithine levels are 10-20 times higher than normal Hyperammonemia is absent because the urea cycle is not disrupted in this deficiency Hyperammonemia occurs in any enzyme deficiency of the Urea cycle

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the urea cycle are true/false? A. Nitrogen of urea comes from alanine and ammonia B. Uses ATP during conversion of Argininosuccinate to arginine C. On consumption of a high amount of protein, excess of urea formed D.Occur mainly in the cytoplasm E. Synthesis of Argininosuccinate consumes energy Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.correct_answer: D. A-F, B-F, C-T, D-T, E-T
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A-F, B-F, C-T, D-T, E-T Consumption of a high amount of protein produces more amino groups, which leads to the formation of excess urea. The urea cycle occurs both in mitochondria and cytoplasm- only two reactions occur in mitochondria and three reactions occur in the cytoplasm. So, we can say that mainly it occurs in the cytoplasm. Synthesis of argininosuccinate requires the use of ATP which gets converted to AMP. The carbon of urea is derived from CO2 or bicarbonate. Nitrogen is derived from ammonia and aspartate.

questions.text: Assertion: Urea synthesis is an energy-requiring process. It consumes total 4 high energy phosphates Reason: 2 ATPs are needed at the carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I step and 2 ATPs at the argininosuccinate synthetase step.

options.label: A
options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently a false/incorrect statement

options.label: D
options.text: Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement.

questions.correct_answer: A. Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion ATP to AMP conversion is counted as 2 ATPs in argininosuccinate synthetase step. In CPS–I reaction: 2 ATP → 2 ADP (2 ATP or 2 high energy phosphates) In AS synthetase: ATP → AMP (1 ATP or 2 high energy phosphates) Total energetics: Either 3ATP or 4 high energy phosphates If both 3ATP and 4ATP options are given, then choose 4 ATP as the best answer because 1 ATP can be considered equivalent to one high-energy phosphate and a total of 4 high-energy-phosphates are equal to 4 ATP. But if the 4 ATP option is not given, then choose 3 ATP

questions.text: Match the following enzyme deficiencies with: Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-d, 2-e, 3-f, 4-c Disease name Enzyme deficiency Hyperammonemia Type I CPS–I(Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase – I) Hyperammonemia Type II (Most common UCD) OTC (Ornithine Transcarbamoylase) Citrullinemia Type I Argininosuccinate synthetase Arginosuccinic aciduria Argininosuccinate Lyase Hyperargininemia Arginase Citrullinemia Type II Citrin(Aspartate–Glutamate Transporter) HHH Syndrome (Autosomal Recessive) Ornithine transporter

questions.text: Arrange the following enzymes of the urea cycle in sequence: a. Arginase b. Arginosuccinate Synthetase c. Argininosuccinate Lyase d. Ornithine Transcarbamoylase Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

d → b → c→ a

questions.text: Nontoxic form of storage and transportation of ammonia:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glutamine Catabolism of amino acids gives rise to ammonia which gets transferred to glutamate. From glutamate, NH3 is ultimately taken up by glutamine which is a Non-toxic form of storage and transportation of ammonia in the blood (see fig below). Glutamine is neutral in nature and can readily move across the cell membrane by facilitative diffusion. Glutamine is formed from glutamate by the following reaction:

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with a urea cycle defect has very high concentrations of blood glutamine and ammonium ion. He was suggested to undergo phenylbutyrate treatment because of it:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Scavenges nitrogen In all urea cycle disorders, there is an accumulation of NH 3 (hyperammonemia) which is very toxic and has to be removed. Urea cycle disorders can be treated: Using scavenging agents: One of the treatments for urea cycle disorder is the use of NH 3 scavenging agents These are Phenylbutyrate and Sodium benzoate Phenylbutyrate reacts with glutamine to get converted into phenyl acetyl glutamine which can be excreted.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Other methods to treat urea cycle disorders: Give Arginine (1st line treatment) An essential amino acid Provides ornithine (required in 2nd step of the urea cycle) Activator of NAGS But it is contraindicated in Arginase deficiency Restrict protein intake to 50% of normal

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a family history of coronary artery disease visited a physician to consult about the occasional episodes of chest pressure behind the sternum when doing some exertional activity but also sometimes at rest. A small number of luminal irregularities without any major obstructions are observed in his coronary angiography. A normal dilation of epicardial blood vessels was observed with the administration of acetylcholine for this procedure. The reaction responsible for this effect involves which of the following amino acid?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Arginine Substances such as acetylcholine, serotonin, and bradykinins mediate the process of vasodilation by attaching to specific membrane receptors present on endothelial cells. This binding causes calcium ion influx into endothelial cells and activates endothelial nitric oxide synthase (eNOS). This enzyme generates nitric oxide from arginine using O2 and cofactors such as NADPH, FAD, FMN, etc. Nitric oxide diffuses into smooth muscles and activates the enzyme guanylyl cyclase and triggers the formation of secondary messenger cGMP from GTP as shown in fig. High levels of cGMP activate protein kinase G causing a reduction of cytosolic calcium levels and relaxation of smooth muscle cells.
